 ¿  An electronic SDS approval process has been implemented which allows all users at any of our sites the ability to view any SDS via the company intranet. 
 ¿  Our Lock-Out/Tag-Out program has gone through an overhaul and training has been completed throughout the company. 
 ¿  The entire region uses the company CEM (Certified Environmental Management) to perform the Industrial Hygiene testing. Each site is tested on a two-year rotation.
 ¿  We have implemented automatic tank gauging which alleviates the need to climb the tanks on a daily basis.

Oil Pollution Act of 1990: U.S. EPA Final Rule for non-Transportation Related on-Shore Facilities as published in 40 CFR Part 112.
 ¿  DOT Part 195 - Transportation of Hazardous Liquids by Pipeline.
 ¿  DOT Part 199 - Drug and Alcohol Testing.
The Roseville Terminal conducts two equipment deployment drills (one un-announced) a year, Quarterly Qualified Individual (QI) drills and an annual table top drill is performed during the annual HAZWOPER training. 
We have an excellent five year accident free history. We have had no accidental releases in the last five years. 
The Roseville Emergency Response Program works together with the Roseville Fire Department. The Roseville employees are not first responders but have received training in the notification process of the Roseville Fire Department (first responder). The employees also participate in an annual evacuation drill, in the event an evacuation is required. 
Various employees at the Roseville Terminal have received CPR/First Aid/AED training, and all employees have received annual HAZWOPER training. Numerous other drills are conducted at the Roseville Terminal as stated previously.
Safety is the #1 core value of our company. Whether in performing everyday work or in the planning and maintenance of project work, safety is top priority. Some of the future improvements towards safety are: 
 ¿  Management and employees have teamed together to pursue the OSHA VPP Star award, which they received in October of 2013 and then were recertified in July of 2016. The next VPP recertification will be in 2021. In this pursuit,  
    there were several changes to improve safety and some of them are;
    o  Quarterly Hazard Identification Audits
    o	Electrical cord quarterly inspection program
    o	First Use Vehicle inspection program
    o	Lifting sling(s) quarterly inspection program
 ¿  The regional office has implemented an electronic MOC process, which helps expedite the approval process and provide a more in

The safety of our employees, contract employees, customers, neighbors and the environment is a core business value and an important priority. Reducing the impact of our operations on the environment is also a priority. NuStar Energy LP is committed to achieving Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) excellence throughout the organization.
NuStar management has also agreed to correct in a timely manner all hazards identified through self inspections, employee reports, accident investigations, or any other means with interim protection as necessary.
We will provide the results of self-inspections and accident investigation to our employees upon request.
We will continuously seek areas for improvement and ways to raise our employee's level of awareness regarding all aspects of safety and health.
The Roseville Terminal was built and put into service in 1947. The Butane addition was added to the Terminal in 2019. The facility was built to store and transport butane (RMP regulated substance), and refined products. The butane is delivered to the terminal via trucks while the refined products are delivered, via a pipeline from the Marathon Mandan, ND. and BPs Whittling, IN. Refineries. The 1,113,075 lbs. of butane, which exceeds the 10,000 lbs. threshold quantity (TQ) of the OSHA PSM requirements, is stored in, one of two, pressurized bullet tanks. The butane is used for blending purposes and is transferred out of the terminal via trucks to downstream customers. 
The Roseville Terminal complies with many different regulatory agencies, which include, but not limited to;
 ¿  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Program (1910.119) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.
 ¿  OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.38(c).
 ¿  OSHA's HAZWOPER Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.120.
 ¿  Federal Oil Pollution Act of 1990: U.S. DOT Final Rule for Transportation Related On-Shore Facilities as published in 49 CFR Part 194 (Response Plans for Onshore Oil Pipelines).
